title: Next continues to weather storm on High Street after online boost offsets fall in store customers
text:
Next continued to weather the storm on the High Street after an online boost offset a fall in store customers.

The fashion chain said sales in shops were 6.3 per cent lower in the third quarter than in the same period last year.

But online sales were up 9.7 per cent.

Onwards and upwards: The fashion chain said sales in shops were 6.3 per cent lower in the third quarter than in the same period last year - but online sales were up 9.7 per cent

Next is widely seen to have dealt with the dramatic change in shopping habits better than many rivals by converting its mail order business into an online platform.

But shares fell 2.9 per cent, or 196p, to 6654p, amid concerns about the outlook. Warm weather led to severely subdued sales in August and September. But this month's chill prompted shoppers to start buying winter clothes, pushing sales up by 5 per cent.

Overall sales rose 2 per cent at the retailer – which has 499 outlets and employs 14,350 people – helped by the growth of its buy now, pay later credit service.

Next maintained its full-year profit guidance of £725m.

The slump in store sales came as MPs called for drastic reform to business rates to protect shops.

In a report today, the House of Commons Treasury committee said the taxes – levied on business premises – were unfair, overly complex and unfit for the way modern businesses run.

And writing in the Mail, the bosses of Tesco and Co-op today add their voice to the clamour for change. Dave Lewis, chief executive of Tesco, and Steve Murrells, chief executive of Co-op, said: 'We are calling on the Government to take urgent action to support the UK's retail sector.'
